bioghist.p: Clifford J. Earle (1904-1982) received his B.D. from McCormick Theological Seminary in 1934. He was pastor of churches in Wisconsin and Illinois, including the Second Presbyterian Church of Oak Park, Illinois (1943-1947). Additionally, he was Chairman, Committee on Social Education and Action, Chicago Presbytery (1943-1947); Moderator of the Chicago Presbytery, 1947-1948; Secretary for Study and Research in the Office of Church and Society of the Board of Christian Education; Secretary of the Office of International Affairs of the UPCUSA; a consultant to the U.S. Mission to the United Nations; and author of How to Help an Alcoholic (1952), and Alcohol and Christian Responsibility (1953).

scopecontent.p: Included in this collection are sermons (1934-1961); articles and speeches (typescripts and some manuscripts) on a range of topics including alcohol, race relations, the women's movement, Christianity and international relations, faith, prayer, and the Christian experience; and reports from the Office of International Affairs of the UPCUSA (of which Earle was Secretary), 1963-1966. Additionally, there is a small amount of correspondence about the Church's 1967 Statement on China (including a letter from Henry Luce about the statement); materials related to the Special Committee to Study Women in Society and in the Church, including minutes, correspondence, and reports, 1967-1969; a report of a 1968 survey of United Presbyterian ministers on civil rights; a survey of "Deliverances of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the USA with reference to war and peace, 1706-1937"; and a small number of materials related to the Wisconsin Christian Endeavor Union, including brochures, newsletters, and reports, 1931-1939.
